The franchise began with the 2009 film ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' and has since grown to include a short film, two television specials, a television series, and a video game. The franchise involves a group of monsters who are assigned by the [[US Government]] to defend [[Earth]] from various [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] and [[supernatural]] threats. ==Feature film== {{main|Monsters vs. Aliens}} ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' is a 2009 American [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] 3-D [[science fiction]] [[action comedy]] [[film]]. It was DreamWorks Animation's first feature film to be directly produced in a [[stereoscopy|stereoscopic]] 3-D format instead of being converted into 3-D after completion, which added $15 million to the film's budget.{{cite news |first= Susan |last= Wloszczyna |title=First look: ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' is the ultimate; a 3-D 'first' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2008-03-10-monsters-aliens_N.htm |work=USA Today|date= March 11, 2008|accessdate=May 16, 2008 }} The film was scheduled for a May 2009 release, but the release date was moved to March 27, 2009. It was released on DVD and Blu-ray September 29, 2009, in North America and included the easter egg to the upcoming movies and previews. The film features the voices of [[Reese Witherspoon]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Hugh Laurie]], [[Will Arnett]], [[Conrad Vernon]], [[Rainn Wilson]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], [[Stephen Colbert]], and [[Paul Rudd]]. ===Possible sequel=== In April 2011, [[Jeffrey Katzenberg]] commented that the studio did not have plans to produce future movie genre parodies, like ''[[Shark Tale]]'', ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', and ''[[Megamind]]'', saying that these films "all shared an approach and tone and idea of parody, and did not travel well internationally. We don't have anything like that coming on our schedule now."{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2011/04/dreamworks-pins-hopes-on-kung-fu-panda-2-after-first-quarter-earnings-fall-short-125845/|title=DreamWorks Animation Pins Hopes On 'Kung Fu Panda 2' After 1Q Earnings Fall Short|last=Lieberman|first=David|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=April 26, 2011|accessdate=August 22, 2015}} ==Short films== ===''B.O.B.'s Big Break''=== ''B.O.B.'s Big Break'' is a 3D animated short film. The short premiered on [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] in 2D on September 26, 2009, and was released 3 days later in 2D and 3D on the ''Monsters vs Aliens'' [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] and the double DVD pack.{{cite news|title=The Smash Hit Comedy, MONSTERS VS. ALIENS, Gets Even Bigger September 29, 2009 on DVD and Blu-ray With the World Premiere of B.O.B.'S BIG BREAK the All New Adventure in Monster 3D|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-smash-hit-comedy-monsters-vs-aliens-gets-even-bigger-september-29-2009-on-dvd-and-blu-ray-with-the-world-premiere-of-bobs-big-break-the-all-new-adventure-in-monster-3d-62145287.html|accessdate=September 9, 2011|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation ''via'' PR Newswire|date=July 8, 2009}} B.O.B., Dr. Cockroach, PhD, and The Missing Link are trying to outwit Captain W.R. Monger to escape from Area 52, the government's top-secret holding cell. Cockroach's escape attempt by feeding B.O.B. a chemical mixture to turn him into a bomb instead results in B.O.B. temporarily acquiring the ability to read minds, and allowing them to find out about a secret exit from Area 52. Unfortunately, the plan fails when B.O.B. smashes the jet they were using to escape believing it to be a [[piñata]], with the resulting explosion erasing B.O.B.'s new power. ===''Night of the Living Carrots''=== {{main|Night of the Living Carrots}} ''Night of the Living Carrots'' is a 2011 13-minute{{cite news|last=Gaudiosi|first=John|title=Nintendo Partners with DreamWorks Animation for Exclusive 3DS Video Content|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/nintendo-3ds-dreamworks-animation-shrek-243627|accessdate=October 4, 2011|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 5, 2011}} 3D Halloween short film based on ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', and a sequel to [[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space|''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'']]. It was directed by Robert Porter. First part of the short premiered on October 13, 2011,{{cite news|title=NINTENDO DOWNLOAD HIGHLIGHTS NEW DIGITAL CONTENT FOR NINTENDO SYSTEMS – OCTOBER 13, 2011|url=http://press.nintendo.com/articles.jsp?id=31189|accessdate=October 13, 2011|newspaper=Nintendo|date=October 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015180844/http://press.nintendo.com/articles.jsp?id=31189|archivedate=October 15, 2011|df=mdy-all}} and the second part five days later,{{cite web|title=Night of the Living Carrots Part 1|url=https://www.nintendo.com/3ds/nintendo-video/detail/lPUX7AWBxl45Xwa_lNh55DBxpYS_KFaA|work=Nintendo|accessdate=October 14, 2011}} for a limited time, exclusively on the [[Nintendo 3DS]] video service.{{cite news|title=ADDING MULTIMEDIA DreamWorks Animation, 3net, Blue Man Group Provide 3D Videos for Nintendo 3DS|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111004005743/en/ADDING-MULTIMEDIA-DreamWorks-Animation-3net-Blue-Man|accessdate=October 4, 2011|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation ''via'' Business Wire|date=October 4, 2011}} It was released on August 28, 2012, on DVD and Blu-ray as a part of ''Shrek's Thrilling Tales'' (''DreamWorks Spooky Stories''). Following the cliff hanger at the end of ''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'', the mutated carrot has spawned hundreds of zombie carrots which once they bite a victim they take control of the subject's mind. Dr. Cockroach determines that the only way to defeat the carrots and free their victims is for B.O.B. to eat all of the carrots (specifically because B.O.B. has no brain and thus is immune to the carrots' mind control powers), which B.O.B eventually, albeit reluctantly, does. At the end of the short, B.O.B. is turned into a giant zombie carrot. ==Television special== ===''Monsters vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space''=== {{main|Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space}} ''Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space'' is a 2009 Halloween special, directed by [[Peter Ramsey]]. It premiered in Ireland on [[RTÉ One]] on October 26, 2009, and aired in USA on the [[NBC]] channel on October 28, 2009.{{cite news|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins From Outer Space|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117941440?refCatId=32|accessdate=August 27, 2011|newspaper=Variety|date=October 23, 2009}} The special was first released on DVD in the UK on September 27, 2010, exclusive to Tesco stores, and in US it was released on September 13, 2011,{{cite web|title=Monsters Vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins Outer Space (2009)|url=https://www.amazon.com/Monsters-Vs-Aliens-Mutant-Pumpkins/dp/B0056YMDVE|work=Amazon|accessdate=August 27, 2011}} and on September 27, 2011,{{cite web|title=Scared Shrekless & Monsters Vs Pumpkins Halloween|url=https://www.amazon.com/Scared-Shrekless-Monsters-Pumpkins-Halloween/dp/B0056YMDSC|work=Amazon|accessdate=August 27, 2011}} along with ''[[Scared Shrekless]]''.{{cite news|title=Scared Shrekless and Monsters vs Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space Halloween Party Double Pack|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Paramount/2011/08/22/scared_shrekless_and_monsters_vs_alien|accessdate=August 27, 2011|newspaper=Starpulse.com|date=August 22, 2011}} It was released on DVD{{cite web|title=Shrek's Thrilling Tales (Widescreen)|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/21014123|publisher=[[Walmart]]|accessdate=July 20, 2012}} and Blu-ray{{cite web|title=Dreamwork's Spooky Stories: Shreks Thrilling Tales / Scared Shrekless / Mutant Pumpkins From Outer Space (Blu-ray) (Widescreen)|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/21014103|publisher=[[Walmart]]|accessdate=July 20, 2012}} on August 28, 2012, as a part of ''Shrek's Thrilling Tales'' (''DreamWorks Spooky Stories''). Susan and the fellow monsters go back to Susan's home in Modesto, California; just in time for Halloween celebrations. Susan spends time with her parents, while the other monsters join in trick-or-treating and collect a large amount of candy. Later, it is revealed that the monsters came to destroy mutant pumpkins disguised as Jack-o-lanterns. When the pumpkins begin to eat children's candies to grow larger, the monsters and children defeat them by throwing excessive candy to bloat them up and explode them. Sta'abi | colspan="4" style="background:lightgrey;"|   | [[Gillian Jacobs]] |} ==Video games== The video game ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens (video game)|Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' was released on March 24, 2009 on [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation 2]], and [[Wii]]. The game, developed by [[Beenox]] and [[Amaze Entertainment]], allows users to play through scenes from the movie as Ginormica, B.O.B., and The Missing Link, and features drop-in/out co-op. Players can play as Dr. Cockroach, PhD in multiplayer co-op, as well as Insectosaurus on the Nintendo DS version of the game. The music was composed by [[James Dooley (composer)|Jim Dooley]], with live brass recorded at the Warner Brothers Eastwood Scoring Stage.{{cite news | author=Dan Goldwasser | url=http://www.scoringsessions.com/news/168/ | title=Jim Dooley scores the ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' video game | publisher=ScoringSessions.com | date=March 9, 2009 | accessdate=March 15, 2009 }} The Monsters Vs. Aliens Videogame has garnered a Metacritic score of 63 for the Xbox 360 version of the title. Another video game titled ''[[Madagascar Kartz]]'' was released by Activision on October 27, 2009, for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Nintendo Wii, and Nintendo DS. Mainly based on the ''[[Madagascar (franchise)|Madagascar]]'' franchise, the game also features B.O.B.{{cite web|last1=Harris|first1=Craig|title=Madagascar Kartz Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/10/30/madagascar-kartz-review|publisher=IGN|accessdate=August 7, 2016|date=October 30, 2009}} and a racetrack based on the spaceship from ''Monsters vs. Aliens.''{{cite web|last1=Sykes|first1=Tom|title=Madagascar Kartz Review|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/madagascar-kartz-10/|publisher=GamesRadar|accessdate=August 7, 2016|date=November 13, 2009}} Another video game titled ''[[Super Star Kartz]]'' was released by Activision on November 15, 2011,{{cite web|title=DreamWorks Super Star Kartz|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/dreamworks-super-star-kartz|work=Metacritic|accessdate=October 28, 2011}} for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, Nintendo Wii, Nintendo DS, and Nintendo 3DS. The game features 14 different characters from DreamWorks' films – ''Monsters vs. Aliens'', ''Madagascar'', ''Shrek'', and ''[[How to Train Your Dragon (franchise)|How to Train Your Dragon]]''.{{cite news|last=O'Connor|first=Alice|title=DreamWorks Super Star Kartz announced|url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/70085/dreamworks-super-star-kartz-announced|accessdate=October 28, 2011|newspaper=Shacknews|date=September 8, 2011}} A free mobile game, titled ''B.O.B.'s Super Freaky Job'', developed by Adrenaline, was released on October 10, 2013 to [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. In the game, player must guide B.O.B. through challenges by rotating the world around him, to obtain spare parts for Dr. Cockroach, and earn stars for the Presidential Medal.{{cite news|title=DreamWorks Animation And Adrenaline Unleash The Monsters With B.O.B.'s Super Freaky Job Mobile Game|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dreamworks-animation-and-adrenaline-unleash-the-monsters-with-bobs-super-freaky-job-mobile-game-227218261.html|accessdate=October 11, 2013|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=October 10, 2013}} ==Chronology== Chronological order of the ''Monsters vs. Aliens'' franchise history: # ''[[B.O.B.'s Big Break]]'' (2009) # ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'' (2009) # ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens: Mutant Pumpkins from Outer Space]]'' (2009) # ''[[Night of the Living Carrots|Monsters vs. Aliens: Night of the Living Carrots]]'' (2011) # [[Monsters vs. Aliens (TV series)|''Monsters vs. Aliens'']] (2013–2014) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.monstersvsaliens.com/}} {{Monsters vs. Aliens}} {{DreamWorks animated films}} [[Category:Science fiction by franchise]] [[Category:DreamWorks Animation franchises]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures franchises]] [[Category:Universal Studios franchises]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Film series introduced in 2009]] [[Category:American animated fantasy films]] [[Category:American animated science fiction films]] [[Category:Animated film series]] [[Category:Science fiction films by series]] [[Category:Comedy films by series]] [[Category:American monster movies]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Computer-animated films]] [[Category:Children's film series]]

{{redirect|Illegal Music|the record label|Illegal Musik}} '''Music [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|piracy]]''' is the copying and distributing of recordings of a piece of music for which the rights owners (composer, recording artist, or [[copyright]]-holding record company) did not give consent. In the contemporary legal environment, it is a form of [[copyright infringement]], which may be either a [[tort|civil wrong]] or a crime depending on jurisdiction. The late 20th and early 21st centuries saw much controversy over the ethics of redistributing media content, how much production and distribution companies in the media were losing, and the very scope of what ought to be considered piracy — and cases involving the piracy of music were among the most frequently discussed in the debate.
==History== The invention of the internet and digital media created music piracy in its modern form. With the invention of newer technology that allowed for the piracy process to become less complicated, it became much more common. Users of the web began adding media files to the internet, and prior potential risks and difficulties to pirating music, such as the physicality of the process, were eliminated. It was much easier for people with little to no knowledge of technology and old piracy methods to gather media files.<ref name="Online Piracy-History">{{cite web|title=Online Piracy-History|url=http://piracy.web.unc.edu/brief-history-of-online-piracy/|website=Online Piracy|publisher=UNC Digital Commons|accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref>
The first application that demonstrated the implications of music piracy was [[Napster]]. Napster enabled users to exchange music files over a common free server without any regard for copyright laws.<ref>{{cite web|title=Internet Piracy|url=http://www.csun.edu/~ch1842/piracy/index.html|accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref> Napster was quickly shut down after lawsuits filed by [[Metallica]] and [[Dr. Dre]] and a separate lawsuit in regards to the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]].<ref name="Online Piracy-History"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Napster settles suits|url=http://money.cnn.com/2001/07/12/news/napster/|accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref> Other music sharing services such as [[Limewire]] continued to be a resource to those searching for free music files. These platforms were also removed after a few years of service due to copyright laws and the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. After finding some loopholes, piracy began to exist in more legal forms, an example being [[Pirate Bay]]. This technical legality was due to the format of the websites and their country of origin and administration. The websites were set up so that the site itself did not host any of the illegal files, but gave the user a map as to where they could access the files. Additionally, in Pirate Bay's case, the website was hosted under Swedish law, where this “map” was not illegal.<ref name="Online Piracy-History"/>
===Arguments over legality=== In face of the growing encroachment on potential sales from internet piracy, industry associations like the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) have lobbied for stricter laws and stricter punishment of those breaking copyright law. Record companies have also turned to technological barriers to copying, such as [[Digital rights management|DRM]], to some [[Digital right management#Controversy|controversy]]. These organizations have tried to add more controls to the digital copy of the music to prevent consumers from copying the music. For the most part, the industry has come to a consensus that, if not DRM, then some similar measures are necessary for them to continue to make a profit.
Critics of the record companies' strategy have proposed that the attempts to maintain sales rates are impeding the rights of legitimate listeners to use and listen to the music as they wish. When the US Congress passed the [[Copyright Act of 1909]], it deliberately gave less copyright control to music composers than that of novelists: "Its fear was the monopoly power of rights holders, and that that power would stifle follow-on creativity".<ref name=lessig /> According to the internationally established [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]],<ref name=oecd /> "Existing laws and regulations may be too broad and general to deal adequately with the rapid technological developments that facilitate digital piracy, and policy makers may need to consider enacting some specific provisions to deal with these infringements. Such provisions should not unduly impede legitimate digital communications, nor unreasonably impact on the Internet as an effective communications platform, commercial channel and educational tool..."<ref name=oecd />
There have been several means of free access to copyrighted music for the general public including Napster, Limewire, and Spotify. Napster was a free file sharing software created by college student Shawn Fanning to enable people to share and trade music files in mp3 format. Napster became hugely popular because it made it so easy to share and download music files. However, the heavy metal band Metallica sued the company for copyright infringement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2000/04/14/mu4.html | work=Forbes | first=Amy | last=Doan | title=Metallica Sues Napster}}</ref> This led to other artists following suit and shutting down Napster’s service. Likewise, Limewire was a free peer-to-peer file sharing software similar to that of Napster. The software enabled unlimited file sharing between computers and ended being one of the most popular sharing networks around. Like Napster, Limewire struggled through multiple legal battles and inevitably wound up being shut down.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/oct/27/limewire-shut-down|title=LimeWire shut down by federal court|author=Josh Halliday|work=the Guardian}}</ref> Spotify and other on-demand streaming services are offering a way for consumers to still get their music for free while also contributing to the musician in a small way instead of simply illegally downloading the music, but it also moves customers away from buying hard copies of music or even legally downloading songs which is severely reducing artists' income. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wlömert|first=Nils|last2=Papies|first2=Dominik|date=2016-06-01|title=On-demand streaming services and music industry revenues — Insights from Spotify's market entry|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167811615001226|journal=International Journal of Research in Marketing|series=The Entertainment Industry|volume=33|issue=2|pages=314–327|doi=10.1016/j.ijresmar.2015.11.002}}</ref>
According to the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) since Shawn Fanning started the program file sharing program Napster in 1999 music revenue has gone down 53% from $14.6 billion to $7.0 billion in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|title = RIAA - Scope Of The Problem - June 14, 2015|url = https://www.riaa.com/physicalpiracy.php?content_selector=piracy-online-scope-of-the-problem|website = riaa.com|accessdate = 2015-06-14}}</ref> A study done in 2007 by the Institute of Policy Innovation states that music piracy resulted in a loss of 71,060 U.S. jobs, out of which 23,860 would have been in the recording industry and 44,200 jobs in other unrelated industries.<ref>http://www.ipi.org/ipi_issues/detail/the-true-cost-of-sound-recording-piracy-to-the-us-economy</ref>
===Law enforcement=== The RIAA, a powerful lobby for the recording industry, is responsible for carrying out most of the lawsuits against music piracy in the United States. Some claim that the enforcement against music piracy, which may cost copyright violators up to $150,000 per infringement,<ref name=lessig /> is unreasonable, and that it may even violate United States constitutional protections against [[cruel and unusual punishment]]. Some have accused the RIAA of outright bullying, as when one of their lawyers, Matt Oppenheimer, told the defendant in one lawsuit, “You don’t want to pay another visit to a dentist like me".<ref name=lessig /> In that same case, according to Lawrence Lessig, "the RIAA insisted it would not settle the case until it took every penny [the defendant] had saved".<ref name=lessig />
Further attempts at progress towards controlling the privacy of public media content by targeting the elimination of piracy were made when the highly anticipated yet often debated bill known as the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA) was passed in recent years. The bill was first introduced in October 2011 by the United States House representative Lamar S. Smith.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-tech/post/house-introduces-internet-piracy-bill/2011/10/26/gIQA0f5xJM_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Cecilia | last=Kang | title=House introduces Internet piracy bill | date=26 October 2011}}</ref> The general scope of the law was to fulfill the goal of putting a stop to online piracy by expanding upon existing criminal laws regarding copyright violations. The essential goal of the bill was to protect intellectual property of content creators by raising awareness of the severity of punishments for copyright infringement. Naturally, the bill was met with considerable opposition from various parties. One instance of this was an article comment by Edward J. Black, president and CEO of the Computer & Communications Industry Association, who questioned the potential effectiveness of the bill by reasoning that the major pirate websites that SOPA attempts to eliminate could just as easily respawn under a different name if taken down as early as a few hours later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/edward-j-black/stop-online-piracy-act-vote_b_1145949.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Internet Users, Free Speech Experts, Petition Against SOPA | date=13 December 2011}}</ref> Additionally, strong protest attempts were made across the internet when numerous high-profile online organizations including Tumblr, Facebook, Twitter, and participating in American Censorship Day on January 18, with some sites including Reddit and Wikipedia going as far as completely blacking out all of their pages, redirecting the user to SOPA protest messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2011-11-16/-american-censorship-day-makes-an-online-statement-the-ticker|title='American Censorship Day' Makes an Online Statement: The Ticker|date=16 November 2011|work=BloombergView.com}}</ref> Ultimately, as a result of aggressive protests and lack of consenting opinions within the congress, SOPA was tabled on January 20 by its creator, House representative Lamar Smith.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2012/01/20/sopa-is-dead-timeline-january-blackout/|title=The Week That Killed SOPA: A Timeline|author=Alex Fitzpatrick|date=20 January 2012|work=Mashable}}</ref>
==Economic ramifications== Piracy's real effect on music sales is difficult to accurately assess. In [[neoclassical economics]] prices are determined by the combination of the forces of [[supply and demand]], but the participators in the digital market do not always follow the usual motives and behaviors of the supply and demand system. First, the cost of digital distribution has decreased significantly from the costs of distribution by former methods. Furthermore, the majority of the filesharing community will distribute copies of music for a zero price in monetary terms, and there are some consumers who are willing to pay a certain price for legitimate copies even when they could just as easily obtain pirated copies,<ref name=oecd /> such as with [[pay what you want]] vendors.
Another issue is that because many people in the world illegally download music because they cannot afford to purchase legitimate copies, not every illegal download necessarily equates to a lost sale. This has some effect on music sales, but as [[Lawrence Lessig]] points out, there is wide asymmetry between the estimated volume of illegal downloading and the projected loss of sales:
{{cquote|In 2002, the RIAA reported that CD sales had fallen by 8.9 percent, from 882 million to 803 million units; revenues fell 6.7 percent. This confirms a trend over the past few years. The RIAA blames Internet piracy for the trend, though there are many other causes that could account for this drop. SoundScan, for example, reports a more than 20 percent drop in the number of CDs released since 1999. That no doubt accounts for some of the decrease in sales... But let’s assume the RIAA is right, and all of the decline in CD sales is because of Internet sharing. Here’s the rub: In the same period that the RIAA estimates that 803 million CDs were sold, the RIAA estimates that 2.1 billion CDs were downloaded for free. Thus, although 2.6 times the total number of CDs sold were downloaded for free, sales revenue fell by just 6.7 percent... [So] there is a huge difference between downloading a song and stealing a CD.<ref name=lessig>{{cite book|last=[[Lawrence Lessig]]|year=2004 |title=Free Culture: How Big Media Uses Technology and the Law to Lock Down Culture and Control Creativity |location=New York |publisher=The Penguin Press |isbn=1-59420-006-8 |oclc=53324884 |ref=harv}}</ref>}}
According to Woolley's introduction each year It is estimated that 12.5 billion dollars are lost due to file sharing and music piracy, and 5 billion of that is profits lost from the music industry directly. Due to this dramatic loss in profits the music industry has been forced to cut down their staffing. Music piracy has become such an issue that the industry is encouraged to adapt to this new era and change.<ref>Woolley, D. J. (2010). The cynical pirate: how cynicism effects music piracy. Academy of Information and Management Sciences Journal, 13(1), 31+. Retrieved from http://bi.galegroup.com.prxy4.ursus.maine.edu/essentials/article/GALE|A241861851/b8772514a705be025bdcd7edee6d5cdc?u=maine_orono</ref>
==Digital copies== The article, "The Music Industry On (The) Line? Surviving Music Piracy In A Digital Era" By Jelle Janssens, Stijn Vandaele, and Tom Vander Beken presents an analysis of the prevalence of piracy in music trade, which has affected the global sales of CDs. This article points out that technological development such as file sharing, MP3 players, and CDRs have increased music piracy. The most common forms of music piracy are Internet Piracy and compact disc piracy. It also discusses the association between music piracy and organized crime, which is defined as profit-driven illegal activities. The fact that digital products are virtual instead of physical affects the economic mechanisms behind the production and distribution of content, and how piracy works for digital as opposed to physical products: "the main consequence of the non-physical form of digital products is their virtually negligible marginal cost of reproduction and their ability to be digitally delivered."<ref name=oecd>{{cite book |editor1-last=Stryszowski |editor1-first=Piotr |editor2-last=Scorpecci |editor2-first=Danny |year=2009 |title=Piracy of Digital Content |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] Publishing |isbn=978-92-64-06543-7 |oclc=663833839 |ref=harv}}</ref> The cost of burning a CD drastically lowered the [[Overhead (business)|overhead]] for record companies, as well as for music pirates, and with the growing tendency toward [[online distribution]] among legitimate and illicit distributors alike, the expense of distributing shrunk further from the costs of printing and transporting CDs to merely the costs of maintaining a [[website]].<ref name=oecd /> By sheer volume of file transfers, though, distributing music through traditional web servers and [[File Transfer Protocol|FTP]] servers were not as popular as [[peer to peer]] (P2P) now, because the traditional [[Direct download link|direct download]] method is slower.
The 2008 British Music Rights survey<ref>[[Andrew Orlowski]]. ''[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/06/16/bmr_music_survey/ 80% want legal P2P - survey]''. [[The Register]], 2008.</ref> showed that 80% of people in Britain wanted a legal P2P service. This was consistent with the results of earlier research conducted in the United States, upon which the [[Open Music Model]] was based.<ref>[[Shuman Ghosemajumder]]. ''[http://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/8438 Advanced Peer-Based Technology Business Models]''. [[MIT Sloan School of Management]], 2002.</ref> In addition, the majority of filesharers in the survey preferred to get their music from "local sources" such as [[Local area network|LAN]] connections, [[email]], [[USB flash drive|flash drives]], sharing with other people they know personally.<ref name=oecd /> The other most common method of filesharing was with P2P technologies. By 2007, P2P networks' popularity had grown so much that they used as much as 39% of the total volume of information exchanged over the internet.<ref name=oecd />
==Rights Holders Solution== Alongside the RIAA and BPI's industry anti-piracy service sit a number of other independent companies offering anti-piracy solutions. These companies tend to have a better reach and success rate than the slower industry bodies and provide an alternative solution. Notable market leaders include [[Audiolock|AudioLock]], Web Sheriff, Topple Track, Detecnet, Muso and Attributor.
==Minimising Online Music Piracy== There are ways to minimise music piracy on using the latest Google court decisions on the [[right to be forgotten]] as well as using some proven techniques relating to adding a watermark to the tracks and uploading the files yourself with promotional intent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mixingmastering.co.uk/music-piracy-how-to-avoid/|title=Music Piracy And How To Avoid It|work=Mixing Mastering Resources for Music, Media and Business}}</ref>
A paper called the '''Music Anti-Piracy Best Practise Guidelines''' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicindie.com/resources/document-library|title=Document library|publisher=}}</ref> has been published by music anti-piracy specialists [http://www.audiolock.net AudioLock] and endorsed by the [[Association of Independent Music]], the Association For Electronic Music (AFEM), [[Digital distribution|music distributors]] Believe Digital and [[Judge Jules]] (DJ and Lawyer). These guidelines give advice on how to minimise exposure to music-piracy and how best to utilise the solutions that are available.
Statistics have shown that since the latter half the 2000s, there has been a decline in music piracy. According to a NPD survey, in 2012, approximately one in ten Internet users in the United States downloaded music through a file sharing service similar to BitTorrent or LimeWire. This number is significantly less than 2005, the peak of the piracy phenomenon, when one in five users used peer-to-peer networks to gather music files. The emergence of free streaming services has decreased the number of users who pirate music on the internet. Services such as [[Spotify]] and [[Pandora Radio|Pandora]] have easy-to-use interfaces and decrease the risk for computer viruses and spyware.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Luckerson|first1=Victor|title=Revenue Up, Piracy Down: Has the Music Industry Finally Turned a Corner?|url=http://business.time.com/2013/02/28/revenue-up-piracy-down-has-the-music-industry-finally-turned-a-corner/|accessdate=23 April 2015|publisher=Time Magazine|date=18 February 2013}}</ref> In comparison to the illegal software used by older music piracy networks such as Napster or Limewire, current music streaming services such as Spotify and Rdio offer cheap yet legal access to copyrighted music by paying the rights holders through money made off of payments made by premium users and through advertisements<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/30081/13-streaming-music-services-compared-by-price-quality-catalog-size-and-more/ | work=Time | title=13 Streaming Music Services Compared by Price, Quality, Catalog Size and More | first=Matt | last=Peckham | date=19 March 2014}}</ref>

{{Start date|1995}} (''de jure'') |until = |sound = United States Navy Band - ¡Oh, gloria inmarcesible!.ogg |sound_title = "National anthem of Colombia" (instrumental) }} The "'''National Anthem of the Republic of Colombia'''" ({{lang-es|Himno Nacional de la República de Colombia}}) is the official name of the [[national anthem]] of [[Colombia]]. It is commonly known by its [[incipit]] "'''¡Oh gloria inmarcesible!'''" ({{Lang-en|"O Unfading Glory"}}), although this is not its official title. It is largely the creation of José Domingo Torres, an actor from Bogotá, who took a poem written by former Colombian president Rafael Núñez and asked a friend, opera singer Oreste Sindici, to set it to music.{{cite web | url=http://nationalanthems.me/colombia-himno-nacional-de-la-republica-de-colombia-oh-gloria-inmarcesible | title=Colombia: Himno Nacional de la República de Colombia (¡Oh gloria inmarcesible!) | publisher=NationalAnthems.me | accessdate=2011-08-15 }} The official announcement of the song came in the form of Act 33 of October 28, 1920. The law 198 of 1995, which legislates national symbols, its broadcast became mandatory for all radio and [[Television in Colombia|television]] in the country both at 6:00 am and at 6:00 pm (the latter half, at various times for private open signal and not applicable to national TV channels by cable), and public addresses of the [[President of Colombia|President of the Republic]] and other official events. ==Lyrics== {{Colombian culture}} {| |- !Spanish lyrics !! Of blood and tears
A river is seen to flow.
In [[Atanasio Girardot|Bárbula]]
neither souls nor eyes,
know whether admiration to feel
or fear to suffer.
|- !IV!!IV |- |A orillas del Caribe,
hambriento un pueblo lucha,
horrores prefiriendo
a pérfida salud.
¡Oh, sí!, de Cartagena
la abnegación es mucha,
y escombros de la muerte
desprecia su virtud.
|| On the shores of the [[Caribbean sea|Caribbean]],
a famished people fight,
preferring horror
to fickle health.
O, aye! from [[Battle of Cartagena de Indias|Cartagena]]
heavy is the hardship,
and death's rubble her virtue disdains
|- !V!!V |- |De Boyacá en los campos,
el genio de la gloria,
con cada espiga un héroe
invicto coronó.
Soldados sin coraza
ganaron la victoria;
su varonil aliento
de escudo les sirvió.
|| From [[Battle of Boyacá|Boyacá]] in the fields,
the genius of glory,
from every sprig a hero
was crowned undefeated.
Soldiers without armor
won the victory;
their virile spirit
served them as a shield.
|- !VI!!VI |- |Bolívar cruza el Ande
que riegan dos océanos,
espadas cual centellas
fulguran en Junín.
Centauros indomables
descienden a los llanos,
y empieza a presentirse,
de la epopeya el fin.
|| [[Simón Bolívar|Bolívar]] crosses the [[Andes]]
bathed by two oceans,
swords as though sparks
flash in [[Battle of Junín|Junín]].
Indomitable centaurs
descend to the plains,
and a premonition begins to be felt,
of the epic's end.
|- !VII!!VII |- |La trompa victoriosa
en Ayacucho truena,
que en cada triunfo crece
su formidable son.
En su expansivo empuje
la libertad se estrena,
del cielo americano
formando un pabellón.
|| The victorious trumpet
in [[Battle of Ayacucho|Ayacucho]] loudly thunders,
as in every triumph grows
its formidable sound.
In its expansive thrust
Liberty is first felt,
from the American sky
forming a pavilion.
|- !VIII!!VIII |- |La virgen sus cabellos
arranca en agonía
y de su amor viuda
los cuelga del ciprés.
Lamenta su esperanza
que cubre loza fría,
pero glorioso orgullo
circunda su alba tez.
|| In agony, the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin]]
Tears out her hair,
and bereft of her love,
leaves it to hang on a cypress.
Regretting her hope
covered by a cold headstone,
but glorious pride
hallows her fair skin.
|- !IX!!IX |- |La patria así se forma,
termópilas brotando;
constelación de cíclopes
su noche iluminó.
La flor estremecida
mortal el viento hallando,
debajo los laureles
seguridad buscó.
|| Thus the motherland is formed,
[[Battle of Thermopylae|Thermopylae]]s bursting forth;
a constellation of cyclops
the night did brighten.
The trembling flower
finding the wind mortal,
underneath the laurels
safety sought.
|- !X!!X |- |Mas no es completa gloria
vencer en la batalla,
que el brazo que combate
lo anima la verdad.
La independencia sola
el gran clamor no acalla;
si el sol alumbra a todos,
justicia es libertad.
|| But it's not complete glory
to defeat in battle,
the arm that fights
is encouraged by truth.
For independence alone
The great clamour doesn't silence;
if the sun shines on everyone,
justice is liberty.
|- !XI!!XI |- |Del hombre los derechos
Nariño predicando,
el alma de la lucha
profético enseñó.
Ricaurte en San Mateo,
en átomos volando,
"Deber antes que vida,"
con llamas escribió.
|| [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen|Of men the rights]]
[[Antonio Nariño|Nariño]]'s preaching,
the soul of struggle
was prophetically taught.
[[Antonio Ricaurte|Ricaurte]] in [[Battle of San Mateo|San Mateo]],
in atoms flying,
"Duty before life,"
with flames he wrote.
|} == Instrumental introduction lyrics == During the [[Colombia–Peru War|border conflict with Peru (1932–1934)]], the soldiers who defended Colombia's national sovereignty added a new verse after the trumpet fanfare. Written specifically for that time of war, it soon fell into disuse.[http://www.archivosonoro.org/?id=75 Eduardo Galeano y Don Quijote de la Mancha] The words are: :Hoy que la madre patria se halla herida, :Hoy que debemos todos combatir, combatir, :Demos por ella nuestra vida :Que morir por la patria no es morir, es vivir : Now when the motherland is wounded, : Now when we must all fight, fight, : Let us give our life for her, : Because to die for one's country is not to die but live. According to José Antonio Amaya,{{Cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-3340627|title=UNA INICIATIVA NORTESANTANDEREANA Buscan meter al general Santander en el Himno|last=Tiempo|first=Casa Editorial El|website=El Tiempo|language=es-CO|access-date=2017-04-19}} elementary school students in the 1930s were taught this stanza. The final line is very similar to a line in the [[national anthem of Cuba]] that goes, "¡Que morir por la patria es vivir!" == Usage == The anthem should be played chorus-verse-chorus. Although the first verse is usually sung between choruses, any of the eleven verses may be used. The anthem should be played chorus-verse-chorus regardless of which verse is selected. This is how it is customarily performed in all public, political, and other important events both public and private. However, it is not uncommon for only the chorus and verse to be played without repeating the chorus. This is usually the case when brevity is sought. By law, radio and television broadcasts must play the national anthem at 6:00 am and 6:00 pm, and the radio invariably uses the shorter format. The shorter anthem is also used at international events such as the Olympic Games or World Cup. In ceremonies of the Colombian Artillery, the last verse is used instead of the first verse.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} The Colombian Cavalry traditionally uses the sixth verse, while the 4th verse is used by the [[Colombian Navy]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://nationalanthems.me/colombia-himno-nacional-de-la-republica-de-colombia-oh-gloria-inmarcesible Colombia: ''Himno Nacional de la República de Colombia (¡Oh gloria inmarcesible!)'' - Audio of the national anthem of Colombia, with information and lyrics] * [http://wsp.presidencia.gov.co/asiescolombia/himno.html: "Letra official del Himno de la República de Colombia"] {{Symbols of Colombia}} {{National Anthems of South America}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Anthem Of Colombia}} [[Category:Colombian songs]] [[Category:National symbols of Colombia]] [[Category:South American anthems|Colombia]] [[Category:Spanish-language songs]] [[Category:1887 songs]] [[Category:National anthems]] [[Category:Compositions in C major]]

[[File:The Thinker Rodin Phila.JPG|thumb|Need for Cognition is associated with deep thought]]
The '''need for cognition''' ('''NFC'''), in [[psychology]], is a [[personality trait|personality variable]] reflecting the extent to which individuals are inclined towards [[Effortfulness|effortful]] cognitive activities.<ref name="Cacioppo1982">{{cite journal | last1 = Cacioppo | first1 = John T. | last2 = Petty | first2 = Richard E. | year = 1982 | title = The need for cognition | url = http://psycinfo.apa.org/doi/index.cfm?fuseaction=showUIDAbstract&uid=1982-22487-001 | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 42 | issue = 1| pages = 116–131 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.42.1.116 }}</ref><ref name="Cacioppo1986">{{cite journal | last1 = Cacioppo | first1 = Rodriguez | last2 = Petty | first2 = John T. | last3 = Kao | first3 = Richard E. | last4 = Feng | first4 = Chuan | last5 = Regina | first5 = | year = 1986 | title = Central and peripheral routes to persuasion: An individual difference perspective | url = http://content.apa.org/journals/psp/51/5/1032.html | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 51 | issue = 5| pages = 1032–1043 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.51.5.1032 }}</ref>
Need for cognition has been variously defined as "a need to structure relevant situations in meaningful, integrated ways" and "a need to understand and make reasonable the experiential world".<ref name="Cohen1955">{{cite journal | last1 = Cohen | first1 = A.R. | last2 = Stotland | first2 = E. | last3 = Wolfe | first3 = D.M. | year = 1955 | title = An Experimental Investigation of Need for Cognition | url = | journal = Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology | volume = 51 | issue = 2| pages = 291–294 | doi=10.1037/h0042761}}</ref> Higher NFC is associated with increased appreciation of debate, idea evaluation, and problem solving. Those with a high need for cognition may be inclined towards [[Elaboration likelihood model#Central route|high elaboration]]. Those with a lower need for cognition may display opposite tendencies, and may process information more [[Heuristic|heuristically]], often through [[Elaboration likelihood model#Peripheral route|low elaboration]].<ref name="Dole1998">{{cite journal | last1 = Dole | first1 = J.A. | last2 = Sinatra | first2 = G.M. | year = 1998 | title = Reconceptualizing Change in the Cognitive Construction of Knowledge | url = | journal = Educational Psychologist | volume = 33 | issue = 2–3| pages = 109–128 | doi=10.1080/00461520.1998.9653294}}</ref>
Need for cognition is closely related to the [[five factor model]] domain [[openness to experience#Measurement|openness to experience]], [[typical intellectual engagement]], and epistemic curiosity (see below).
==History== Cohen, Stotland and Wolfe (1955),<ref name="Cohen1955"/> in their work on individual differences in cognitive motivation, identified a "''need for cognition''" which they defined as "the individual's need to organize his experience meaningfully", the "need to structure relevant situations in meaningful, integrated ways", and "need to understand and make reasonable the experiential world" (p. 291). They argued that, if this "need" were frustrated, it would generate "feelings of tension and deprivation" that would instigate "active efforts to structure the situation and increase understanding" (p. 291), though the particular situations arousing and satisfying the need may vary (p. 291). Cohen argued that even in structured situations, people high in NFC see ambiguity and strive for higher standards of cognitive clarity.
Cohen and colleagues<ref name="Cohen1955"/><ref name="Cohen1957">Cohen, A.R. (1957). "Need for Cognition and Order of Communication as Determinants of Opinion Change," 79–97. In Hovland, C.I. (ed.), ''The Order of Presentation in Persuasion'', Yale University Press, (New Haven).</ref> themselves identified multiple prior identifications of need for cognition, citing works by [[Gardner Murphy|Murphy]], [[Abraham Maslow|Maslow]], Katz, [[Harry Harlow|Harlow]] and [[Solomon Asch|Asch]]<ref>Murphy, G. ''Personality''. New York: Harper, 1947</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Maslow | first1 = A.H. | year = | title = A theory of human motivation | url = | journal = Psychol. Rev. | volume = 1943 | issue = 50| pages = 370–396 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Katz | first1 = D. | last2 = Sarnoff | first2 = I. | year = | title = Motivational bases of attitude change | url = | journal = J. Abnorm. Soc. Psychol. | volume = 1954 | issue = 49| pages = 115–124 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Harlow | first1 = H.F. | last2 = Harlow | first2 = M.K. | last3 = Meyer | first3 = D. | year = | title = Learning motivated by a manipulation drive | url = | journal = J. Exp. Psychol. | volume = 1950 | issue = 40| pages = 228–234 }}</ref><ref>Asch, S.E. ''Social Psychology''. New York, Prentice-Hall, 1952".</ref> They<ref name="Cohen1955" /> distinguished their concept from the apparently similar "intolerance of ambiguity" proposed by [[Else Frenkel-Brunswik|Frenkel-Brunswik]],<ref name="Brunswik1949">{{cite journal | last1 = Frenkel-Brunswik | first1 = E | year = 1949 | title = Intolerance of ambiguity as an emotional and perceptual personality variable | url = | journal = J. Pers. | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 108–143 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.1949.tb01236.x}}</ref> arguing that NFC does not reflect the need to experience an integrated and meaningful world. Contemporary research suggests that Cohen's conception of need is, however, closer to tolerance of ambiguity, need for structure, or need for cognitive closure than to current ideas of need for cognition. For instance, studies using Cohen's measures indicated avoidance of ambiguity and a need to get "meaning" even if this meant relying on heuristics or expert advice rather than careful scrutiny of incoming information.<ref name="Cacioppo1996">{{cite journal|last=Cacioppo|first=John T.|author2=Petty, Richard E. |author3=Feinstein, Jeffrey A. |author4= Jarvis, W. Blair G. |title=Dispositional Differences in Cognitive Motivation: The Life and Times of Individuals Varying in Need for Cognition|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=March 1996|volume=119|issue=2|pages=197–253|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.119.2.197}}</ref>
Building on this work, [[John T. Cacioppo|Cacioppo]] therefore moved away from drive-reduction toward measuring [[Differential psychology|individual differences]] in the self-reward potential of cognitive activity,<ref name="Thompson1993">{{cite journal | last1 = Thompson | first1 = E.P. | last2 = Chaiken | first2 = S. | last3 = Hazlewood | first3 = J.D. | year = 1993 | title = Need for Cognition and Desire for Control as Moderators of Extrinsic Reward Effects: A Person × Situation Approach to the Study of Intrinsic Motivation | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 64 | issue = 6| pages = 987–999 | doi=10.1037/0022-3514.64.6.987}}</ref>{{rp|988}} stressing (p. 118) that they were using the word need in the statistical sense of a "likelihood or tendency", rather than in the rudimentary biological sense of "tissue deprivation", they defined the need for cognition as an individual's tendency to "engage in and enjoy thinking" (p. 116) and the tendency to "organize, abstract, and evaluate information" (p. 124)—or, variously, as a stable, but individually different "tendency to engage in and enjoy effortful cognitive endeavors", or an "intrinsic motivation to engage in effortful cognitive endeavors... and exercise their mental faculties",<ref name="Cacioppo1996" />{{rp|197}} or an "intrinsic motivation for effortful thought".<ref name="Thompson1993" />{{rp|997}}
Cacioppo and Petty (1982) created their own 34-item scale to measure the need for cognition. Two years later, an 18-item version was published<ref name="Cacioppo1984">{{cite journal | last1 = Cacioppo | first1 = J.T. | last2 = Petty | first2 = R.E. | last3 = Kao | first3 = C.F. | year = 1984 | title = The Efficient Assessment of Need for Cognition | url = | journal = Journal of Personality Assessment | volume = 48 | issue = 3| pages = 306–307 | doi=10.1207/s15327752jpa4803_13| pmid = 16367530 }}</ref> and in most of the cases reported in the subsequent literature it is this amended scale that is administered. Recently, a 6-item version of the need for cognition scale was proposed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lins de Holanda Coelho|first=Gabriel|last2=H. P. Hanel|first2=Paul|last3=J. Wolf|first3=Lukas|date=2018-08-10|title=The Very Efficient Assessment of Need for Cognition: Developing a Six-Item Version|journal=Assessment|language=en|pages=107319111879320|doi=10.1177/1073191118793208|pmid=30095000|issn=1073-1911}}</ref>
==Features== People high in the need for cognition are more likely to form their attitudes by paying close attention to relevant arguments (i.e., via the [[Elaboration likelihood model#Central route|central route to persuasion]]), whereas people low in the need for cognition are more likely to rely on [[Elaboration likelihood model#Peripheral route|peripheral cues]], such as how attractive or credible a speaker is. People low in need for cognition are also more likely to rely on stereotypes alone in judging other people than those high in need for cognition.<ref name=Cacioppo2000>{{cite book|title=Handbook of Individual Differences in Social behavior|year=2009|publisher=The Guilford Press|location=New York/London|isbn=978-1-59385-647-2|pages=318–329|author=Petty, Richard E.|author2=Briñol, P |author3=Loersch, C. |author4=McCaslin, M.J. |editor=Leary, Mark R. |editor2=Hoyle, Rick H.|chapter=Chapter 21. The Need for Cognition}}</ref>
Psychological research on the need for cognition has been conducted using self-report tests, where research participants answered a series of statements such as "I prefer my life to be filled with puzzles that I must solve" and were scored on how much they felt the statements represented them. The results have suggested that people who are high in the need for cognition scale score slightly higher in verbal intelligence tests but no higher in abstract reasoning tests.<ref name="Cacioppo1996"/>
Research has concluded that individuals high in NFC are less likely to attribute higher social desirability to more attractive individuals or to mates.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Perlini|first=Arthur H.|author2=Hansen, Samantha|title=Moderating effects of need for cognition on attractiveness stereotyping|journal=Social Behavior and Personality: An International Journal|year=2001|volume=29|issue=4|pages=313–321|doi=10.2224/sbp.2001.29.4.313}}</ref> College students high in NFC report higher [[life satisfaction]].<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCR/is_2_38/ai_n6130140/print The need for cognition and life satisfaction among college students]</ref>
A study on [[lucid dreaming]] found that frequent and occasional lucid dreamers scored higher on NFC than non-lucid dreamers.<ref name=Cacioppo2000/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Blagrove|first=M|author2=Hartnell, S.J.|title=Lucid dreaming: associations with internal locus of control, need for cognition and creativity|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|year=2000|volume=28|pages=41–47|url=http://files.meetup.com/1675783/Lucid%20dreaming_cognition_creativity_locus%20of%20control.pdf|doi=10.1016/S0191-8869(99)00078-1|access-date=2011-12-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426045505/http://files.meetup.com/1675783/Lucid%20dreaming_cognition_creativity_locus%20of%20control.pdf|archive-date=2012-04-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> This suggests there is continuity between waking and dreaming cognitive styles. Researchers have argued that this is because self-reflectiveness or self-focused attention is heightened in lucid dreams and also is associated with greater need for cognition.
===Relationship to intelligence=== A number of studies have found moderate correlations between NFC and measures of verbal intelligence. One study found that need for cognition had a moderate positive correlation with [[fluid intelligence]] (reasoning ability, particularly verbal, and to a lesser extent numeric and figural reasoning), and a weaker correlation with [[crystallised intelligence]] (knowledge), which had much smaller positive correlations.<ref name=Monika/>
===Dual-system theory=== NFC has been incorporated into Epstein's dual-system theory of personality called [[cognitive-experiential self-theory]].<ref name=Cacioppo2000/> The theory proposes that people have two information processing systems, a rational system and an experiential system. The rational system is thought to be logical, verbal and relatively unemotional. The experiential system is thought to be intuitive, based on images and highly reliant on emotion. A modified version of the Need for Cognition scale has been used to assess individual differences in the rational system, whereas the experiential system has been assessed using a scale called Faith in Intuition.
Research shows that the two system are uncorrelated and hence independent of each other. That is individuals either high or low in need for cognition may also make use of their intuitions in forming judgments. In fact, individuals high and low in need for cognition respectively may make use of their intuitions in differing ways. When individuals give little thought to their judgments these judgments may be influenced directly by emotions, intuitions, and images in an automatic way. On the other hand, those who are high in need for cognition tend to give more thought to their judgments, and the thoughts generated may be indirectly biased by their emotions, intuitions, and images. Hence individuals high in need for cognition are not necessarily more "rational" than those low in this trait, if their faith in intuition is also high. Rather, their "irrational" intuitions tend to be given more thoughtful elaboration than those who are low in need for cognition and yet also high in faith in intuition.<ref name=Cacioppo2000/>
===Biases and decision making=== NFC is associated with the amount of thought that goes into making a decision. Both high and low levels of the trait may be associated with particular biases in judgment. People low in need for cognition tend to show more bias when this bias is due to relying on mental shortcuts, that is, heuristic biases. People high in this trait tend to be more affected by biases that are generated by effortful thought.<ref name=Cacioppo2000/>
====False memories==== High need for cognition is associated with a greater susceptibility to the creation of false memories associated with certain learning tasks. In a commonly used research paradigm, participants are asked to memorise a list of related words. Recognition is tested by having them pick out learned words from a set of studied and non-studied items. Certain non-studied items are conceptually related to studied items (e.g., ''chair'' if the original list contained ''table'' and ''legs''). People high in NFC are more likely to show [[false memory]] for these lures, due to their greater elaboration of learned items in memory as they are more likely to think of semantically related (but non-studied) items.<ref name=Cacioppo2000/>
====Halo effects==== A bias associated with low need for cognition is the [[halo effect]], a phenomenon in which attractive or likeable people tend to be rated as superior on a variety of other characteristics (e.g., intelligence). People low on NFC are more likely to rely on stereotypes rather than individual features of a person when rating a novel target. People high in NFC still show a halo effect however, albeit a smaller one, perhaps because their thoughts about the target are still biased by the target's attractiveness.<ref name=Cacioppo2000/>
==Relationship with personality traits==
===Related constructs=== NFC has been found to be strongly associated with a number of independently developed constructs, specifically epistemic curiosity, [[typical intellectual engagement]], and [[openness to experience#Measurement|openness to ideas]].<ref name=Mussell>{{cite journal|last=Mussell|first=Patrick|title=Epistemic curiosity and related constructs: Lacking evidence of discriminant validity|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|year=2010|volume=49|pages=506–510|url=http://www.citeulike.org/article/7387092|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2010.05.014|issue=5}}</ref> * Epistemic [[curiosity]] can be defined as “desire for knowledge that motivates individuals to learn new ideas, eliminate information-gaps, and solve intellectual problems”.<ref name=Mussell /> * Typical intellectual engagement was proposed by Goff and Ackerman (1992) and was defined as a "personality construct that represents an individual’s aversion or attraction to tasks that are intellectually taxing".<ref name=Mussell /> * Openness to ideas is a facet of [[openness to experience]] associated with "aspects of being open minded, engaging in unconventional thoughts, and solving problems and thinking as an end in itself".<ref name=Mussell /> ::Based on the very large positive correlation between NFC and typical intellectual engagement (''r'' = .78) it has been argued that they may be essentially the same construct.<ref name=Woo>{{cite journal|last=Woo|first=S.E. |author2=Harms, P.D. |author3=Kuncel, N.R|title=Integrating personality and intelligence: Typical intellectual engagement and need for cognition|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|year=2007|volume=43|pages=1635–1639|url=http://www.mendeley.com/research/integrating-personality-and-intelligence-typical-intellectual-engagement-and-need-for-cognition/|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2007.04.022|issue=6}}</ref> * Further studies have found that NFC, typical intellectual engagement, epistemic curiosity, and openness to ideas were all strongly intercorrelated. [[Factor analysis]] showed that measures of all four constructs loaded strongly onto a single factor suggesting they all share a common conceptual basis.<ref name=Mussell /> ::The author of this study argued that although the four constructs lack [[discriminant validity]] they are not necessarily all conceptually equivalent as each one may emphasise particular aspects of functioning more than others. * A study comparing need for cognition and openness to ideas using confirmatory factor analysis found that although the two constructs were very strongly related they were not redundant. NFC and openness to ideas had somewhat contrasting correlation patterns with other personality traits. ::For example, NFC was more strongly correlated with emotional stability and activity than openness to ideas, whereas openness to ideas was more strongly correlated with [[novelty seeking|novelty]] and [[sensation seeking|experience seeking]] than NFC.<ref name=Monika/>
===Other personality characteristics=== * Within the [[Big Five personality traits|Big Five]] model of personality, NFC has been found to relate positively to [[openness to experience]] most strongly and to a more moderate extent to [[conscientiousness]], particularly the competence and achievement striving facets, and to relate inversely to an extent to [[neuroticism]].<ref name=Monika>{{cite journal|doi=10.1177/0146167209351886|title=Same or Different? Clarifying the Relationship of Need for Cognition to Personality and Intelligence|year=2009|last1=Fleischhauer|first1=M.|last2=Enge|first2=S.|last3=Brocke|first3=B.|last4=Ullrich|first4=J.|last5=Strobel|first5=A.|last6=Strobel|first6=A.|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin|volume=36|pages=82–96|pmid=19901274|issue=1|citeseerx=10.1.1.1026.1579}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/00223989709603517|title=Need for Cognition in the Big-Five Factor Structure|year=1997|last1=Sadowski|first1=Cyril J.|last2=Cogburn|first2=Helen E.|journal=The Journal of Psychology|volume=131|issue=3|pages=307–312}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|pmid=10402681|year=1999|last1=Pacini|first1=R|last2=Epstein|first2=S|title=The relation of rational and experiential information processing styles to personality, basic beliefs, and the ratio-bias phenomenon|volume=76|issue=6|pages=972–87|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.76.6.972}}</ref> * Regarding [[Cloninger]]'s temperament traits, NFC has been related negatively to [[harm avoidance]] and positively to [[persistence (psychology)|persistence]] and was unrelated to [[reward dependence]] or [[novelty seeking]].<ref name=Monika/> * NFC has only a weak positive relationship with [[sensation seeking]], specifically a weak correlation with the boredom susceptibility subscale but no relationship to the other subscales.<ref name=Monika/> * NFC has a modest inverse correlation with [[negative affect]]. NFC had no significant correlation with a broad measure of overall positive affect, although it was positively correlated with feelings of activity, interest, and alertness.<ref name=Monika/> * NFC has been positively related to other, theoretically unrelated, personality characteristics such as [[self-esteem]], masculine sex-role attitudes, and [[absorption (psychology)|absorption]]. * NFC is negatively related to [[social anxiety]] (more strongly in females than males).<ref name=osberg>{{cite journal|last=Osberg|first=Timothy M.|title=The Convergent and Discriminant Validity of the Need for Cognition Scale|journal=Journal of Personality Assessment|year=1987|volume=3|pages=441–450|doi=10.1207/s15327752jpa5103_11|pmid=16372844|issue=3}}</ref><ref name=Phares>{{cite book|title=Introduction to personality|year=1997|publisher=Longman|location=New York|isbn=978-0-673-99456-1|author=Phares, E.J.|edition=Fourth|author2=Chaplin, W.F.|page=521|chapter=Chapter 15. Personality and Intellect}}</ref> * It has been speculated that people who more carefully analyse their world feel a greater sense of mastery, and hence greater self-esteem, although it is also possible that higher self-esteem may lead to greater motivation to engage in thinking. * NFC may be related to masculine sex-role due to the stereotype associating masculinity with rationality. * Regarding absorption, people high in NFC may find it easier to devote their attentional processes exclusively to intellectual tasks. * Regarding social anxiety, it is possible that greater attention to cognitive activity may be associated with reduced attention to social cues associated with negative evaluation.<ref name=osberg/> *NFC is positively related to stimulation, self-direction, and universalism values, and negatively to security and conformity values.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lins de Holanda Coelho|first=Gabriel|last2=H. P. Hanel|first2=Paul|last3=J. Wolf|first3=Lukas|date=2018-08-10|title=The Very Efficient Assessment of Need for Cognition: Developing a Six-Item Version|journal=Assessment|language=en|pages=107319111879320|doi=10.1177/1073191118793208|pmid=30095000|issn=1073-1911}}</ref>
==Consumers== Research has shown that high-need for cognition consumers prefer advertising that features open-ended comparative advertising which allows consumers to decide which brand is best.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Martin | first1 = Brett A. S. | last2 = Lang | first2 = Bodo | last3 = Wong | first3 = Stephanie | year = 2004 | title = Conclusion Explicitness in Advertising: The Moderating Role of Need for Cognition and Argument Quality | url = http://www.basmartin.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/Martin-Lang-Wong-2004.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Journal of Advertising | volume = 32 | issue = 4| pages = 57–65 | doi=10.1080/00913367.2003.10639148| citeseerx = 10.1.1.506.5890 }}</ref>
NFC has also offered insights into how people respond to alternative web site designs. Martin, Sherrard and Wentzel (2005) demonstrate that high-need for cognition people prefer web sites with high verbal complexity (more in-depth information) and low visual complexity (static images rather than animations).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Martin|first=Brett A. S. |author2=Sherrard, Michael J. |author3=Wentzel, Daniel|title=The Role of Sensation Seeking and Need for Cognition on Web-Site Evaluations: A Resource-Matching Perspective|journal=Psychology and Marketing|year=2005|volume=22|issue=2|pages=109–126|doi=10.1002/mar.20050|url=http://www.basmartin.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/Martin-Sherarrd-Wentzel2005.pdf}}</ref>

The [[Persian language]] has six [[vowel]] [[phoneme]]s and twenty-three [[consonant]] phonemes. It features contrastive [[stress (linguistics)|stress]] and [[syllable]]-final [[consonant cluster]]s.
==Vowels== [[File:Farsi vowel chart.svg|thumb|upright=1.4|right|The vowel phonemes of Tehrani Persian.]] The chart to the right reflects the vowels of many educated Persian speakers from Tehran.<ref name="ipa_handbook">{{cite book | title=Handbook of the International Phonetic Association: A guide to the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet | year=1999 | author=International Phonetic Association | location=Cambridge | publisher=Cambridge University Press | isbn=978-0-521-63751-0 | pages=124–125 | chapter=Persian (Farsi) | chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/rosettaproject_pes_phon-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=George L.|authorlink1=George Campbell (linguist)|title=Concise compendium of the world's languages|date=1995|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0415160499|page=385|edition=1st publ.|chapter=Persian}}</ref>
The three vowels {{IPAslink|æ}}, {{IPAslink|e}} and {{IPAslink|o}} are traditionally referred to as 'short' vowels and the other three ({{IPAslink|ɒ|ɒː}}, {{IPAslink|i|iː}} and {{IPAslink|u|uː}}) as 'long' vowels. In fact the three 'short' vowels are short only when in an open syllable (i.e. a syllable ending in a vowel) that is non-final (but can be unstressed or stressed), e.g. {{nastaliq|صدا|fa}} {{IPA|[seˈdɒː]}} 'sound', {{nastaliq|خدا|fa}} {{IPA|[xoˈdɒː]}} 'God'. In a closed syllable (i.e. a syllable ending in a consonant) that is unstressed, they are around sixty percent as long as a long vowel; this is true for the 'long' vowel {{IPA|/iː/}} as well. Otherwise the 'short' and 'long' vowels are all pronounced long. Example: {{nastaliq|سفتر|fa}} {{IPA|[seˑfˈtʰæːɾ]}} 'firmer'.<ref name=Toos>Toosarvandani, Maziar D. 2004 [http://people.ucsc.edu/~mtoosarv/papers/toosarvandani_2004_JRAS.pdf "Vowel Length in Modern Farsi"], JRAS, Series 3, 14, 3, pp. 241–251.</ref>
When the short vowels are in open syllables, they are also unstable and tend in informal styles to assimilate in quality to the following long vowel. Thus {{nastaliq|دویست|fa}} {{IPA|[deˈviːst]}} 'two hundred' becomes {{IPA|[diˈviːst]}}, {{nastaliq|شلوغ|fa}} {{IPA|[ʃoˈluːɢ]}} 'crowded' becomes {{IPA|[ʃuˈluːɢ]}}, {{nastaliq|رسیدن|fa}} {{IPA|[ræsiːˈdæːn]}} 'to arrive' becomes {{IPA|[resiːˈdæːn]}} and so on.<ref name=Toos />
Word-final {{IPA|/o/}} is rare except for {{nastaliq|تو|fa}} {{IPA|/to/}} ('you' [singular]), loanwords (mostly of Arabic origin), and proper and common nouns of foreign origin, and word-final {{IPA|/æ/}} is very rare in Iranian Persian, an exception being {{nastaliq|نه|fa}} {{IPA|/næ/}} ('no'). The word-final {{IPA|/æ/}} in Early New Persian mostly shifted to {{IPA|/e/}} in contemporary Iranian Persian (often romanized as {{angbr|eh}}, meaning {{IPA|[e]}} is also an allophone of {{IPA|/æ/}} in word-final position in contemporary Iranian Persian), but is preserved in the Eastern dialects.
===Diphthongs=== The status of [[diphthongs]] in Persian is disputed.<ref name=Windfuhr1979>{{cite book|last1=Windfuhr|first1=Gernot L.|title=Persian grammar: History and State of its Study|date=1979|publisher=Mouton|isbn=9027977747|page=137|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0g8n9mmnjKgC&pg=PA137}}</ref><ref name=Alamolhoda>{{cite journal|last1=Alamolhoda|first1=Seyyed Morleza|title=Phonostatistics and Phonotactics of the Syllable in Modern Persian|journal=Studia Orientalia|date=2000|volume=89|pages=14–15|url=http://ojs.tsv.fi/index.php/StOrE/issue/view/3422|issn=0039-3282}}</ref> Some authors list {{IPA|/ei̯, ou̯, ɒi̯, oi̯, ui̯/}},<ref name=Windfuhr1979/> others list only {{IPA|/ei̯/}} and {{IPA|/ou̯/}}, but some do not recognize diphthongs in Persian at all.<ref name=Windfuhr1979/><ref name=Alamolhoda/> A major factor that complicates the matter is the change of two classical and pre-classical Persian diphthongs: {{IPA|/ai̯/ > /ei̯/}} and {{IPA|/au̯/ > /ou̯/}}. This shift occurred in Iran but not in some modern varieties (particularly of Afghanistan).<ref name=Windfuhr1979/> Morphological analysis also supports the view that the alleged Persian diphthongs are combinations of the vowels with {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}}.<ref name=Alamolhoda/>
The Persian orthography does not distinguish between the diphthongs and the consonants {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}}; that is, they both are written with {{lang|fa|ی}} and {{lang|fa|و}} respectively.
{{IPA|/ou̯/}} becomes {{IPAblink|o|oː}} in the colloquial Tehran dialect but is preserved in other Western dialects and standard Iranian Persian.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}

In the modern Persian alphabet, the short vowels {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/o/}}, {{IPA|/æ/}} are usually left unwritten, as is normally done in [[Arabic alphabet]]. (See {{slink|Arabic phonology|Vowels}}.)
===Historical shifts=== Early New Persian inherited from [[Middle Persian]] eight vowels: three short ''i, a, u'' and five long ''ī, ē, ā, ō, ū'' (in [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|/i a u/}} and {{IPA|/iː eː aː oː uː/}}). It is likely that this system passed into the common Persian era from a purely quantitative system into one where the short vowels differed from their long counterparts also in quality: ''i'' > {{IPAblink|ɪ}}; ''u'' > {{IPAblink|ʊ}}; ''ā'' > {{IPAblink|ɑː}}. These quality contrasts have in modern Persian varieties become the main distinction between the two sets of vowels.<ref name="rees2008">{{cite thesis|last=Rees|first=Daniel A.|year=2008|type=Ph.D.|title=Towards Proto-Persian: An Optimality Theoretic Historical Reconstruction|chapter=From Middle Persian to Proto-Modern Persian}}</ref>
The inherited eight-vowel inventory is retained without major upheaval in [[Dari language|Dari]], which also preserves quantitative distinctions.<ref name="rastorgueva1982">{{cite book | title=Основы иранского языкознания | year=1982 | author1=Ефимов В. А. | author2=Расторгуева B. C. | author3=Шарова Е. Н.| chapter=Персидский, таджикский, дари | volume=3. Новоиранские языки: западная группа, прикаспийские языки. | publisher=Наука | location=Moscow | pages=5—315}}</ref>
In [[Western Persian]], two of the vowel contrasts have been lost: those between the tense mid and close vowels. Thus ''ē'', ''ī'' have merged as {{IPAblink|i}}, while ''ō'', ''ū'' have merged as {{IPAblink|u}}. In addition, the lax close vowels have been lowered: ''i'' > {{IPAblink|e}}, ''u'' > {{IPAblink|o}}. The lax open vowel has become fronted: ''a'' > {{IPAblink|æ}}, and in word-final position further raised to {{IPAblink|e}}. Modern Iranian Persian does not feature distinctive vowel length.<ref>{{cite book | title=Грамматика современного литературного персидского языка | year=2001 | author=Рубинчик Ю. А. | publisher=Восточная литература | location=Moscow | isbn=5-02-018177-3 | page=19 }}</ref>
In both varieties ''ā'' is more or less labialized, as well as raised in Dari. Dari ''ō'' is also somewhat fronted.<ref name="rastorgueva1982"/>
Tajiki has also lost two of the vowel contrasts, but differently from Western Persian: here the tense/lax contrast among the close vowels has been eliminated. That is, ''i'', ''ī'' have merged as {{IPAslink|ɪ}}, and ''u'', ''ū'' have merged as {{IPAslink|ʊ}}. The other tense back vowels have shifted as well. Mid ''ō'' has shifted front: {{IPAslink|ɵ}} or {{IPAslink|ʉ}}, a vowel usually romanized as ''ů''. Open ''ā'' has been labialized and raised to an open-mid vowel {{IPAslink|ɔ}}.
Loanwords from [[Arabic]] generally undergo these changes as well.

M.|date=1993-05-01|publisher=Ibex Publishers|isbn=0-936347-29-5|edition=3rd Rev|page=xvii|chapter=The Phonology of Persian}}</ref>
===Allophonic variation=== Alveolar stops {{IPAslink|t}} and {{IPAslink|d}} are either [[Apical consonant|apical]] [[Alveolar consonant|alveolar]] or [[Laminal consonant|laminal]] [[Denti-alveolar consonant|denti-alveolar]]. The [[voiceless]] [[obstruent]]s {{IPA|/{{IPA link|p}}, {{IPA link|t}}, {{IPA link|t͡ʃ}}, {{IPA link|k}}/}} are [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]] much like their English counterparts: they become aspirated when they begin a syllable, though aspiration is not [[Complementary distribution|contrastive]].<ref name="mahootian1997">{{cite book | title=Persian | year=1997 | last=Mahootian | first=Shahrzad | publisher=Routledge | location=London | isbn=0-415-02311-4 | pages=287, 292, 303, 305 }}</ref> The Persian language does not have syllable-initial consonant clusters ([[#Phonotactics|see below]]), so unlike in English, {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} are aspirated even following {{IPAslink|s}}, as in {{nastaliq|هستم|fa}} {{IPA|/ˈhæstæm/}} ('I exist').<ref name="mace1993">{{Cite book | publisher = Teach Yourself | isbn = 0-8442-3815-5 | last = Mace | first = John | title = Modern Persian | date = March 1993 }}</ref> They are also aspirated at the end of syllables, although not as strongly.
The [[velar]] stops {{IPA|/{{IPA link|k}}, {{IPA link|ɡ}}/}} are [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]] before [[front vowel]]s or at the end of a syllable.
In Classical Persian, the [[uvular]] consonants {{nastaliq|غ|fa}} and {{nastaliq|ق|fa}} denoted the original Arabic phonemes, the fricative {{IPAblink|ɣ}} and the plosive {{IPAblink|q}}, respectively. In modern [[Tehrani Persian]] (which is used in the Iranian mass media, both colloquial and standard), there is no difference in the pronunciation of {{nastaliq|غ|fa}} and {{nastaliq|ق|fa}}, and they are both normally pronounced as a voiced stop {{IPAblink|ɢ}}. The classic pronunciations of {{nastaliq|غ|fa}} and {{nastaliq|ق|fa}} are preserved in the eastern varieties, [[Dari language|Dari]] and [[Tajik language|Tajiki]], as well as in the southern varieties (e.g. [[Zoroastrian Dari language]] and other Central / Central Plateau or [[Kermanic languages]]).
The [[alveolar flap]] {{IPAslink|ɾ}} has a [[Trill (phonetics)|trilled]] allophonic variant {{IPAblink|r}} at the beginning of a word (it is sometimes a free variation between a trill {{IPA|[r]}} and a flap {{IPA|[ɾ]}});<ref name="mahootian1997"/> the trill {{IPA|[r]}} as a separate phoneme occurs word-medially especially in loanwords of Arabic origin as a result of gemination of {{IPA|[ɾ]}}. An [[approximant]] {{IPAblink|ɹ}} also occurs as an allophone of {{IPA|/ɾ/}} before {{IPA|/t, d, s, z, ʃ, l, ʒ/}}; {{IPA|[ɹ]}} is sometimes in free variation with {{IPA|[ɾ]}} in these and other positions, such that {{nastaliq|فارسی|fa}} ('Persian') is pronounced {{IPA|[fɒːɹˈsiː]}} or {{IPA|[fɒːɾˈsiː]}} and {{lang|fa|سقرلات}} ('scarlet') {{IPA|[sæɣeɹˈlɒːt]}} or {{IPA|[sæɣeɾˈlɒːt]}}. {{IPA|/r/}} is sometimes realized as a long approximant {{IPA|[ɹː]}}.
The [[velar nasal]] {{IPAblink|ŋ}} is an allophone of {{IPAslink|n}} before {{IPA|/k, ɡ/}}
{{IPA|/f, k, s, ʃ, x/}} may be voiced to, respectively, {{IPA|[{{IPA link|v}}, {{IPA link|ɡ}}, {{IPA link|z}}, {{IPA link|ʒ}}, {{IPA link|ɣ}}]}} before voiced consonants; {{IPA|/n/}} may be bilabial {{IPAblink|m}} before [[bilabial consonant]]s. Also {{IPA|/b/}} may in some cases change into {{IPAblink|β}}, or even {{IPAblink|v}}; for example {{nastaliq|باز|fa}} ('open') may be pronounced {{IPA|[bɒːz]}} as well as {{IPA|[βɒːz]}} or {{IPA|[vɒːz]}} and/or {{IPA|[vɒː]}}, colloquially.
===Dialectal variation=== The pronunciation of {{nastaliq|و|fa}} {{IPAblink|w}} in Classical Persian shifted to {{IPAblink|v}} in Iranian Persian and Tajik, but is retained in Dari. In modern Persian {{IPA|[w]}} may be lost if preceded by a consonant and followed by a vowel in one whole syllable, e.g. {{nastaliq|خواب|fa}} {{IPA|/xwɒb/ > [xɒb]}} 'sleep', as Persian has no syllable-initial consonant clusters ([[Persian phonology#Phonotactics|see below]]).
